question.title: Translate escaped string from XML file
question.body:
Let's assume I have the string "F%c3%bcr%20alle" in a xml file. It should translate to "Für alle". I can do the unescaping with JavaScript:

let decoded = decodeURIComponent("F%c3%bcr%20alle");

And with C#:

var decoded = HttpUtility.UrlDecode("F%c3%bcr%20alle");

But what I need is Java on Android. I tried

String decoded = URLDecoder.decode("F%c3%bcr%20alle", StandardCharsets.UTF_8);

but the result is "FÃ¼r alle".

Any ideas?

Update: As user85421 pointed out this is not an issue of Java's URLDecoder.decode() but the real problem seems to be that Logcat doesn't output UTF-8 ... ? The debugger shows the expected value in the tooltip.

Update: Someone requested an example xml ...

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<d:multistatus xmlns:d="DAV:" xmlns:s="http://sabredav.org/ns" xmlns:oc="http://owncloud.org/ns" xmlns:nc="http://nextcloud.org/ns">
<d:response>
    <d:href>/next/remote.php/dav/files/xyz/F%c3%bcr%20alle/</d:href>
</d:response>
</d:multistatus>

question_comments.body: Update: Someone requested an example xml ... Yes, that makes a lot more sense. That is a URL with URL encoding inside that XML file. So it would need to be decoded as one. That variable decoded almost certainly contains the correct value, so it's what you're doing later(still mysterious) with it that's the problem
I would certainly welcome seeing an example from this XML file instead of a short arbitrary string
I’m voting to close this question because it has changed too much since it was asked; a new question needs to be asked instead.

Let's assume I have the string "F%c3%bcr%20alle" in a xml file. You probably shouldn't. That style of encoding is really for URLs. And you can tell that by the fact that the space has been encoded. It should normally be "Für alle"
I use the Logcat Tool Window integrated in Android Studio. No external Editor involved.

(Not to leave you hanging: Logcat supports UTF-8, no doubt. However, [A] you need to tell logcat to write UTF-8, and [B] when you open your log file, you need to tell your editor to open it as UTF-8. Every tool that converts chars to bytes or vice versa needs to be told what charset encoding to use; textfiles don't contain this value! - and files are 'bytes'. So, logcat AND your editor AND any tools in between ALL need to be told. Clearly at least one isn't picking the right charset encoding. The solution to your problem is something like 'pass --charset=UTF-8 when opening the log file'.

I'm voting to close because the fundamental nature of the question is invalid (which OP already figured out as per the Update at the end). Feel free to re-ask a question specifically about the charset encoding issue. I think, OP, you don't quite fully understand the space yet, so you might want to do that.
TextView shows the correct value ... anyway I think it's irritating that Logcat shows something different than the debugger.
I recommend focusing on how you are going to use this string. My guess is that it is designed to be displayed to the user (e.g., TextView, Text() composable). Does it display properly there?
My output is Android Studio's logcat with Log.d ... but you're probably right ... Log.d([..], "Für alle") also results in "FÃ¼r alle"
